message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: AutoGen: Enabling Next-Gen LLM Applications via Multi-Agent Conversation
Paper Abstract: AutoGen is an open-source framework that allows developers to build LLM applications via multiple agents that can converse with each other to accomplish tasks. AutoGen agents are customizable, conversable, and can operate in various modes that employ combinations of LLMs, human inputs, and tools. Using AutoGen, developers can also flexibly define agent interaction behaviors. Both natural language and computer code can be used to program flexible conversation patterns for different applications. AutoGen serves as a generic infrastructure to build diverse applications of various complexities and LLM capacities. Empirical studies demonstrate the effectiveness of the framework in many example applications, with domains ranging from mathematics, coding, question answering, operations research, online decision-making, entertainment, etc.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Natural Language Processing

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP involves computer activity in which computers analyze, understand, alter, or generate natural language, including the automation of linguistic forms like conversation, correspondence, reading, translation, and dictation.

### Key Processing Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

### Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Until the 1980s, most NLP systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

### Modern Advances

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, and the concept of large language models (LLM) emerged in the late 2010s.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced NLP capabilities, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP involves computer activity in which computers analyze, understand, alter, or generate natural language, including the automation of linguistic forms like conversation, correspondence, reading, translation, and dictation.

### Key Processing Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

### Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Until the 1980s, most NLP systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

### Modern Advances

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, and the concept of large language models (LLM) emerged in the late 2010s.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced NLP capabilities, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Here are the web search results for "Operations Research":

## Definition and Overview

Operations research (OR) is a branch of applied mathematics that deals with the development and application of analytical methods to improve management and decision-making.(no content)OR encompasses a wide range of problem-solving techniques and methods including simulation, mathematical optimization, queueing theory, stochastic-process models, Markov decision processes, and other analytical approaches.(no content)It is most often used to analyze complex real-world systems, typically with the goal of improving or optimizing performance.

## Applications and Industries

Since World War II, operational research has expanded into a field widely used in industries ranging from petrochemicals to airlines, finance, logistics, and government.

## History

The origin of modern operations research can be traced to the study of inventory management with economic order quantity developed by Ford W. Harris in 1913.(no content)Modern operational research originated at the Bawdsey Research Station in the UK in 1937, and during the Second World War close to 1,000 men and women in Britain were engaged in operational research.

## Academic Organizations

The International Federation of Operational Research Societies (IFORS) is an umbrella organization for national operations research societies of over 45 countries, officially founded in 1959.

Links: [{"title":"Question answering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Question_answering"},{"title":"What Is Enlightenment? - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Answering_the_Question:_What_is_Enlightenment%3F"},{"title":"Question and answer system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Question_and_answer_system"},{"title":"Template:HD/del - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:HD/del"},{"title":"Código de Investigación - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%C3%B3digo_de_Investigaci%C3%B3n"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference Desk philosophies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_Desk_philosophies"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Question Answering:

## Overview

Question-answering research attempts to develop ways of answering a wide range of question types, including fact, list, definition, how, why, hypothetical, semantically constrained, and cross-lingual questions.

## Types of Question Answering Systems

There are several categories of question answering:

- **Reading Comprehension QA**: Answering questions related to an article in order to evaluate reading comprehension is one of the simpler form of question answering, since a given article is relatively short compared to the domains of other types of question-answering problems.

- **Closed-book QA**: Closed-book question answering is when a system has memorized some facts during training and can answer questions without explicitly being given a context. This is similar to humans taking closed-book exams.

- **Closed-domain QA**: Closed-domain question answering deals with questions under a specific domain (for example, medicine or automotive maintenance) and can exploit domain-specific knowledge frequently formalized in ontologies.

- **Open-domain QA**: Open-domain question answering deals with questions about nearly anything and can only rely on general ontologies and world knowledge.

## Technical Approaches

Rule-based systems use a set of rules to determine the correct answer to a question. Statistical systems use statistical methods to find the most likely answer to a question.

## Q&A Systems

A question and answer system (or Q&A system) is an online software program that attempts to answer its users' questions. Examples include platforms like Stack Exchange, Quora, and various community-based Q&A sites.

Web search results for query: "Dialogue Systems"

Links: [{"title":"Dialogue system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_system"},{"title":"Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_Concerning_the_Two_Chief_World_Systems"},{"title":"Spoken dialog system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_dialog_systems"},{"title":"Collaborative language systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_language_systems"},{"title":"Cultivating New Frontiers in Agriculture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultivating_New_Frontiers_in_Agriculture"},{"title":"Michael Witbrock - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witbrock,_Michael"},{"title":"Sustained Dialogue Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sustained_Dialogue_Institute"},{"title":"Issue-based information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issue-based_information_system"},{"title":"Systems of Survival - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_of_Survival"},{"title":"System (typeface) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_(typeface)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Dialogue Systems:

## Definition and Overview

A dialogue system, or conversational agent (CA), is a computer system intended to converse with a human.(no content)Dialogue systems employed one or more of text, speech, graphics, haptics, gestures, and other modes for communication on both the input and output channel.

## Core Components

Principal to any dialogue system is the dialogue manager, which is a component that manages the state of the dialogue, and dialogue strategy.(no content)The semantic information is analysed by the dialogue manager, which keeps the history and state of the dialogue and manages the general flow of the conversation. Usually, the dialogue manager contacts one or more task managers, that have knowledge of the specific task domain.

## Spoken Dialogue Systems

A spoken dialog system (SDS) is a computer system able to converse with a human with voice.(no content)It has two essential components that do not exist in a written text dialog system: a speech recognizer and a text-to-speech module.

## Applications

Dialogue systems can support a broad range of applications in business enterprises, education, government, healthcare, and entertainment.(no content)Simple dialogue systems are widely used to decrease the human workload in call centers. In this and other industrial telephony applications, the functionality provided by dialogue systems is known as interactive voice response or IVR.

## Modern Developments

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.

Links: [{"title":"Dialogue system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_system"},{"title":"Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_Concerning_the_Two_Chief_World_Systems"},{"title":"Spoken dialog system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_dialog_systems"},{"title":"Collaborative language systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_language_systems"},{"title":"Cultivating New Frontiers in Agriculture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultivating_New_Frontiers_in_Agriculture"},{"title":"Michael Witbrock - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witbrock,_Michael"},{"title":"Sustained Dialogue Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sustained_Dialogue_Institute"},{"title":"Issue-based information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issue-based_information_system"},{"title":"Systems of Survival - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_of_Survival"},{"title":"System (typeface) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_(typeface)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Dialogue Systems:

## Definition and Overview

A dialogue system, or conversational agent (CA), is a computer system intended to converse with a human.(no content)Dialogue systems employed one or more of text, speech, graphics, haptics, gestures, and other modes for communication on both the input and output channel.

## Core Components

Principal to any dialogue system is the dialogue manager, which is a component that manages the state of the dialogue, and dialogue strategy.(no content)The semantic information is analysed by the dialogue manager, which keeps the history and state of the dialogue and manages the general flow of the conversation. Usually, the dialogue manager contacts one or more task managers, that have knowledge of the specific task domain.

## Spoken Dialogue Systems

A spoken dialog system (SDS) is a computer system able to converse with a human with voice.(no content)It has two essential components that do not exist in a written text dialog system: a speech recognizer and a text-to-speech module.

## Applications

Dialogue systems can support a broad range of applications in business enterprises, education, government, healthcare, and entertainment.(no content)Simple dialogue systems are widely used to decrease the human workload in call centers. In this and other industrial telephony applications, the functionality provided by dialogue systems is known as interactive voice response or IVR.

## Modern Developments

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.

Web search results for query: "Human-in-the-loop"

Links: [{"title":"Human-in-the-loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-in-the-loop"},{"title":"Humans in the Loop (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humans_in_the_Loop_(film)"},{"title":"Reciprocal human machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_human_machine_learning"},{"title":"User-in-the-loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-in-the-loop"},{"title":"Hardware-in-the-loop simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardware-in-the-loop_simulation"},{"title":"Human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–computer_interaction"},{"title":"Human performance modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_performance_modeling"},{"title":"Looped (TV series) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Looped_(TV_series)"},{"title":"Ring (novel series) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_(novel_series)"},{"title":"Humanistic intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanistic_intelligence"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **Human-in-the-loop (HITL)**:

## Definition

Human-in-the-loop (HITL) is used in multiple contexts and can be defined as a model requiring human interaction.

## Key Characteristics

HITL allows the user to change the outcome of an event or process, and the immersion effectively contributes to a positive transfer of acquired skills into the real world.(no content)Humans typically still need to take the information provided by a system to determine the next course of action based on their judgment and experience.

## Applications

HITL is associated with modeling and simulation (M&S) in the live, virtual, and constructive taxonomy.(no content)A real-world example of HITL simulation as an evaluation tool is its usage by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to allow air traffic controllers to test new automation procedures by directing the activities of simulated air traffic while monitoring the effect of the newly implemented procedures.

Other applications include training pilots with flight simulators and testing new processes before deployment.

## Advantages

HITL simulations bring to the surface issues that would not otherwise be apparent until after a new process has been deployed.(no content)As with most processes, there is always the possibility of human error, which can only be reproduced using HITL simulation.

Human-in-the-loop represents a crucial approach where human judgment and experience remain essential despite advances in automation and AI.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-Agent Programming Contest - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-Agent_Programming_Contest"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of Multi-Agent Systems based on the search results:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Capabilities and Benefits

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)Intelligence may include methodic, functional, procedural approaches, algorithmic search or reinforcement learning.

## Components

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment.(no content)Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents, however, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Key Characteristics

Agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with decentralization so no agent is designated as controlling.(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Communication

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement, with example languages being Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

Links: [{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Category:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Writing articles with large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Writing_articles_with_large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"1.58-bit large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1.58-bit_large_language_model"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models/Archive 5 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models/Archive_5"}]

Here are the search results for "Large Language Models":

## Overview

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Key Capabilities

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.(no content)LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

## Technical Characteristics

These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.(no content)As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

Here are the search results for "Large Language Models":

## Overview

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Key Capabilities

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.(no content)LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

## Technical Characteristics

These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.(no content)As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

I've completed a web search for "Conversational AI." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A conversational user interface (CUI) is a user interface for computers that emulates a conversation with a human.(no content)Conversational interfaces use natural language processing (NLP) to allow computers to understand, analyze, and create meaning from human language.

## Key Technologies

Modern chatbots typically use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.(no content)AI chatbots typically use a foundational large language model, such as GPT-4 or the Gemini language model, which is fine-tuned for specific uses.

## Types of Conversational AI

There are two main categories of conversational interfaces: voice assistants and chatbots. A voice user interface allows a user to complete an action by speaking a command.(no content)A chatbot is a web- or mobile-based interface that allows the user to ask questions and retrieve information.

## Business Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.(no content)Conversational commerce is e-commerce done via various means of conversation (live support on e-commerce websites, online chat using messaging apps, chatbots on messaging apps or websites, voice assistants) and using technology such as speech recognition, speaker recognition, natural language processing and artificial intelligence.

Web search results for query: "Programming Language"

Links: [{"title":"Programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programming_language"},{"title":"List of programming languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_programming_languages"},{"title":"The C Programming Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_C_Programming_Language"},{"title":"Esoteric programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language"},{"title":"C (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_(programming_language)"},{"title":"R (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Go (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Go_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Scratch (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scratch_(programming_language)"},{"title":"List of C-family programming languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_C-family_programming_languages"},{"title":"History of programming languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_programming_languages"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about programming languages:

## Definition

A programming language is an artificial language for expressing computer programs, and programming languages typically allow software to be written in a human readable manner.

## Implementation Approaches

There are two main approaches for implementing a programming language – compilation, where programs are compiled ahead-of-time to machine code, and interpretation, where programs are directly executed.(no content)In addition to these two extremes, some implementations use hybrid approaches such as just-in-time compilation and bytecode interpreters.

## Historical Development

The first programmable computers were invented during the 1940s, and with them, the first programming languages, which were first-generation programming languages (1GLs) consisting of machine language.(no content)The introduction of high-level programming languages (third-generation programming languages—3GLs)—revolutionized programming, as these languages abstracted away the details of the hardware, instead being designed to express algorithms that could be understood more easily by humans.

## Notable Languages and Examples

The search results mention several important languages:
- In 1957, Fortran (FORmula TRANslation) was invented, often considered the first compiled high-level programming language.
- Most popular imperative languages—including C, Pascal, Ada, C++, Java, and C#—are directly or indirectly descended from ALGOL.
- Go is a high-level, general-purpose programming language that is statically-typed and compiled.
- Scratch is a high-level, block-based visual programming language and website aimed primarily at children as an educational tool.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've performed a web search for "Decision Making" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In psychology, decision-making is regarded as the cognitive process resulting in the selection of a belief or a course of action among several possible alternative options.(no content)It could be either rational or irrational.

## Key Aspects of Decision-Making

**Analysis and Evaluation:** A major part of decision-making involves the analysis of a finite set of alternatives described in terms of evaluative criteria, then ranking these alternatives in terms of how attractive they are to the decision-maker(s), or finding the best alternative when all criteria are considered simultaneously.

**Environmental Influence:** Studies show that more complex environments correlate with higher cognitive function, and cognitive function is greatly affected by higher measures of environmental complexity, making it easier to think about the situation and make a better decision.

**Types of Decision-Making:** In situations with higher time pressure, higher stakes, or increased ambiguities, experts may use intuitive decision-making rather than structured approaches, following a recognition-primed decision that fits their experience.

## Challenges in Decision-Making

**Decision Fatigue:** Decision fatigue is the tendency for people's decision making to become impaired as a result of having recently taken multiple decisions.(no content)Decision fatigue impairs one's ability to make decisions efficiently, makes them prone to over-reliance on heuristics and biases, reduces one's ability to make trade-offs, and can even lead to avoiding making decisions.

**Analysis Paralysis:** Analysis paralysis is the state that a person enters where they are unable to make a decision, wherein one is unable to make a decision because they get stuck going over the information again and again for fear of making the wrong decision.

## Specialized Decision-Making Contexts

The search results also cover various specific types of decision-making, including consensus decision-making, military decision-making processes, data-informed decision-making, and decision-making under deep uncertainty.

Here are the web search results for "Machine Learning":

## Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms: supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## History

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Neural Networks

In machine learning, a neural network or neural net (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks, consisting of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons.

The search results contain extensive information about machine learning foundations, history, techniques, and applications from Wikipedia sources.

Web search results for query: "Software Framework"

Links: [{"title":"Software framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_framework"},{"title":"List of Eclipse Modeling Framework based software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Eclipse_Modeling_Framework_based_software"},{"title":"Software Testing Automation Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_Testing_Automation_Framework"},{"title":"Orleans (software framework) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orleans_(software_framework)"},{"title":"Electron (software framework) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electron_(software_framework)"},{"title":"Tauri (software framework) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tauri_(software_framework)"},{"title":"GigaMesh Software Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GigaMesh_Software_Framework"},{"title":"Avalonia (software framework) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avalonia_(software_framework)"},{"title":"Application framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_framework"},{"title":"Category:Software frameworks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Software_frameworks"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about software frameworks:

## Definition

A software framework is software that provides reusable, generic functionality which developers can extend or customize to create complete solutions.(no content)It offers an abstraction layer over lower-level code and infrastructure, allowing developers to focus on implementing business logic rather than building common functionality from scratch.

## Key Characteristics

Software frameworks differ from standard libraries in that they implement inversion of control—in a framework, the framework controls the flow and calls user code at specific points, often via the Template Method Pattern.(no content)Frameworks provide pre-implemented functionality (e.g., standard features or workflows) that can be used as-is or customized within a predefined structure.

## Purpose and Benefits

A framework is intended to enhance productivity by allowing developers to focus on satisfying business requirements rather than reimplementing generic functionality.(no content)For example, a team using a web framework to develop a banking website can focus on writing banking business logic rather than handling low-level details like web request processing or state management.

## Examples

Some well-known software frameworks include:
- Electron, a free and open-source framework designed to create desktop applications using web technologies (mainly HTML, CSS and JavaScript) that are rendered using a version of the Chromium browser engine and a back end using the Node.js runtime environment.
- Tauri, an open-source framework designed to create cross-platform desktop and mobile applications on Linux, macOS, Windows, Android and iOS using a web frontend.

Based on the search results, here's information about software frameworks:

## Definition

A software framework is software that provides reusable, generic functionality which developers can extend or customize to create complete solutions.(no content)It offers an abstraction layer over lower-level code and infrastructure, allowing developers to focus on implementing business logic rather than building common functionality from scratch.

## Key Characteristics

Software frameworks differ from standard libraries in that they implement inversion of control—in a framework, the framework controls the flow and calls user code at specific points, often via the Template Method Pattern.(no content)Frameworks provide pre-implemented functionality (e.g., standard features or workflows) that can be used as-is or customized within a predefined structure.

## Purpose and Benefits

A framework is intended to enhance productivity by allowing developers to focus on satisfying business requirements rather than reimplementing generic functionality.(no content)For example, a team using a web framework to develop a banking website can focus on writing banking business logic rather than handling low-level details like web request processing or state management.

## Examples

Some well-known software frameworks include:
- Electron, a free and open-source framework designed to create desktop applications using web technologies (mainly HTML, CSS and JavaScript) that are rendered using a version of the Chromium browser engine and a back end using the Node.js runtime environment.
- Tauri, an open-source framework designed to create cross-platform desktop and mobile applications on Linux, macOS, Windows, Android and iOS using a web frontend.

Links: [{"title":"API - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/API"},{"title":"Open API - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_API"},{"title":"Web API - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_API"},{"title":"Application binary interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_binary_interface"},{"title":"Windows API - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_API"},{"title":"Application Programming Interface for Windows - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_Programming_Interface_for_Windows"},{"title":"Category:Application programming interfaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Application_programming_interfaces"},{"title":"API (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/API_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"List of Microsoft Windows application programming interfaces and frameworks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Microsoft_Windows_application_programming_interfaces_and_frameworks"},{"title":"Linux kernel interfaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux_kernel_interfaces"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about APIs (Application Programming Interfaces):

## Definition

An application programming interface (API) is a connection between computers or between computer programs, serving as a type of software interface that offers a service to other pieces of software.

## Key Characteristics

APIs are a type of software interface, offering a service to other pieces of software. More specifically, an application programming interface (API) defines access in source code, which is a relatively high-level, hardware-independent, and human-readable format.

## Types of APIs

- **Web APIs**: A web API is an application programming interface (API) for either a web server or a web browser.(no content)A server-side web API consists of one or more publicly exposed endpoints to a defined request–response message system, typically expressed in JSON or XML by means of an HTTP-based web server.

- **Open APIs**: An open API (often referred to as a public API) is a publicly available application programming interface that provides developers with programmatic access to a (possibly proprietary) software application or web service.

## Historical Development

British computer scientists Maurice Wilkes and David Wheeler worked on a modular software library in the 1940s for EDSAC, an early computer, with subroutines stored on punched paper tape and a "library catalog" of notes that would today be called an API specification.(no content)The web API is now the most common meaning of the term API.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
